newsitem.title: UK: EIB well-placed to fund European jobs scheme.
newsitem.headline: EIB well-placed to fund European jobs scheme.

text.p: The European Investment Bank (EIB), a key player in an EU compromise plan on Monday that met France's demands for action on jobs growth, has long been one of the premier borrowers in international bond markets.

The EIB is the European Union's (EU) main financing arm and, as such, can command the finest pricing available for its international bond issues. It is often able to get better levels than many sovereign credits.
"The EIB is a great name and will easily be able to boost its borrowing in the capital markets," a Eurobond syndicate head at a U.S. bank said.

The focus of its activity is large, long-dated deals aimed at institutional investors. It raised 18.6 billion Ecu ($21 billion) on international markets in 1996 via 22 bond issues. It also taps retail investors.

The EIB, which lent 23 billion Ecu ($26 billion) last year, has now been given a broader mandate to lend funds to small businesses and high technology firms for job creation, under a plan announced by by European Monetary Affairs Commissioner Yves-Thibault de Silguy.

While there will be no new EU money for jobs projects, EU finance ministers saw the EIB as a source of specific funding for new employment as they strove to finalise the so-called stability pact aimed at keeping national budgets tight post-EMU.
The EIB had, to a certain extent, forecast such a task for itself.

Last December, EIB president Brian Unwin told Reuters in an interview that its role as a lender may grow after monetary union if reduced government spending to meet Maastricht criteria required the EIB to lend more after economic and monetary union (EMU).
EU law says the third stage of EMU, including introduction of the EU's planned single currency, the euro, must take place no later than January 1, 1999.
